something with such a dedicated fanbase getting to experience it in a new way
at the very least tag them please
summary: We’re almost halfway through the month (almost there, guys!) so I just wanted to take this opportunity to be That Person for a...
body:
We’re almost halfway through the month (almost there, guys!) so I just wanted to take this opportunity to be That Person for a minute.

For anyone who might be seeing it before the 31st, and I cannot stress this enough, please do not post spoilers. And before anyone @s me like “but Remy, the book has been out for 30 years,” this is really important to me. We know there is going to be new content and old content in new ways and every fan should get to experience that as an experience, rather than a series of squealing posts and images on tumblr. After the 31st, do whatever, but please consider keeping screenshots and spoilers to yourself until we all can enjoy them together. 

Alright. Soapbox off.

tags: bc michael sheen was the bar tender android and i had an epiphany
summary: Good Omens passengers!au not based off the disaster that is the movie but based off this post where Aziraphale is the android...
body:
Good Omens passengers!au not based off the disaster that is the movie but based off this post where Aziraphale is the android bar tender who at first is just an android who thinks like an android, moves like an android, and who’s life is all about cleaning glasses that have never been used and whose existence is narrowed down to just this bar and its empty seats, this long 90 year journey upon a ship called Eden. he was made to wait, to serve, to make cocktails and easy conversation. and then one day, to end up in a landfill on some distant planet, never to awake again.

so imagine his surprise when, one day, in comes a very confused, very pissed off man who should be asleep. it’s 10 years into the journey. there’s still 80 years ahead of them. he shouldn’t be awake he should be asleep. yet here is this passenger, with an endearing lisp and a shock of deep deep red upon his head, standing upright and telling Aziraphale that he’s going to die, he’s going to die before he gets to do what he had wanted to do, what he had boarded this godforsaken ship to do, so can he have a glass of their finest sherry please? thank you.

this passenger is Crowley, and as the days progress, the reality of the situation gets less and less dire when Crowley starts to accept his fate, his horrid luck, and begins to make the most out of his situation. suddenly, Aziraphale’s days are no longer just about his bar and his glasses, but now more and more about this anxious optimist who drowns his qualms about living in drink and Aziraphale’s company, in turning all the floors of the Eden ship into actual Eden, who goes to each sleeping pod with Aziraphale in tow, talking to those inside, having hacked into their files to pass the time, telling them stories. making up some of his own.

And Aziraphale is an android, through and through. but he’d been programmed to be a learning android, so that he could adapt, be the easy going stranger-friend every bar tender is to their punch drunk patrons. and the longer he is with Crowley, the more and more he becomes less like an android and more like a human, who fusses over this man who drinks far more than usual, who was lonely way before boarding, and who is even more lonely now. who little by little opens up to Aziraphale until they’re both laughing like old friends, until Crowley drags his sleeping pod into the room Aziraphale’s bar is in, until he says; “I don’t like to be away from you for too long– you’re all I have.”

and it’s true. Crowley has no one else. but Aziraphale’s learned to tell the difference between what is true on the surface and what is true beneath it all. they’ve become something, them two. something intertwined and in sync. Aziraphale has become all Crowley is not willing to lose. and Crowley is all Aziraphale has, too.

but Crowley is human. and Aziraphale is an android. years go by. plants grow. stories, both made up and real, take on twists and turns. red hair turns grey. wrinkles form around eyes. hands that had let all the plants on Eden’s upper decks grow turn gnarled and feeble. Aziraphale looks the same, but Crowley is approaching 90 and the ship hasn’t even landed on homestead yet.

and Azira hasn’t thought about death in awhile. before Crowley, he’s never had to. but now, sat next to a dying man who has been his whole world for the past 70 years or so, Aziraphale finds himself staring at it in the face as Crowley presses his cheek into Azira’s hand.

“where do androids go, when they die?” Crowley asks in a near whisper.

Aziraphale cannot lie– it’s the one thing he hasn’t learned. Crowley had no need to lie to him. He says; “a landfill, I suppose.”

This makes his passenger chuckle. “I’d do anything to be in that landfill with you– you’re all I have.”

and that’s the last thing he ever says

—

fast forward, 20 years later. the ship lands and those in the higher ups rush to hide the evidence of any malfunction, a mission they’d been preparing for since word of Crowley’s sleeping pod opening before its time was sent to HQ. if news like this gets out, people would never trust them again. so they purge everything.

part of the purge is the wiping of the memories of the bar android Aziraphale.

it isn’t successful.

Aziraphale is stubborn, holding on to what he can. when they think they’ve got every last bit, pieces of Crowley show up. weedle their way into his movements, into his tendency to reach for the sherry wine instead of anything else they have in store, into his tendency to call any one in front of him “dearest”, “dear”, and “my love”.

in the end, they disassemble him and tip him into a landfill.

in the end, Aziraphale disappears, just as Crowley did.

and no one finds out.

summary: good omens headcanon
title: good omens headcanon
body:
im too lazy to write it properly but…

ineffable husbands get engagement rings…

Aziraphale gets this one

and Crowley gets this one

if anyone (whose not human or the antichrist) ask they make up really outlandish dumb reasons for wearing the ring.
- it’s my pet… I got a pet… I wasn’t very good at having a pet.
-it reminds me I can fly…
-I found it and thought it looked neat so now I never take it off
-Shakespeare knew I was immortal and had left it too me to receive in the future

- I won it at a quiz but it’s cursed so I can’t take it off.

-thor gave it to me… what do you mean he’s not real?!?!??

- I found it in some cream cheese

anyway thought id share :-)

summary:
assuming aziraphale and crowley can, if they put the effort in, shapeshift at will, please consider:
aziraphale and crowley as...
body:
assuming aziraphale and crowley can, if they put the effort in, shapeshift at will, please consider:

  • aziraphale and crowley as mermen. crowley uses this skill to scare the bananas out of people trying to swim the english channel. aziraphale uses it to make little kids believe 
  • crowley pouting over this or that thing and turning back into his snake, all thick coils of red and black scales, hiding himself in his plants, and then here comes aziraphale, shining with white and butterscotch yellow scales, curling insistently around crowley until he’s ready to come back
  • a golden retriever and an english bulldog walk unattended through st james’ park. the english bulldog wears a little tartan collar; the golden retriever is a little embarrassed because it’s a little more…friendly than what he intended but follows the bulldog anyway.
  • oh to be a ladybug and a fly on the wall 
  • “I know you’re there,” an exasperated adam young says to an empty room with a tea cup and a peppercorn grinder on a table. “told you he’d see through it,” the peppercorn grinder murmurs, narrowly avoiding a swat from the arm of the tea cup as aziraphale flings himself back into his body. 
  • crowley occasionally impersonates the queen, if only to take advantage of the excellent breakfast spread. aziraphale strongly disapproves, but he really loves the particular jam and honey combination that’s laid out for her every morning, and therefore usually attends as a very grouchy albert
  • aziraphale is very bad at children’s magic, but he can miracle as well as anybody else in heaven. if he’s going to do that, however, he wants to look the part, so as not to raise suspicion–a unicorn, most often, though sometimes an alien, sometimes a faerie. he wishes crowley would stop ruining the effect by showing up as a gremlin in the aftermath, but at least it means the humans don’t stick around too long. 
  • crowley turning himself into an actual child to spread rumors about the monster that lives under the bed. aziraphale turns himself into the light under the bed that makes a kid feel warm and safe to look at. 
  • once, crowley catches aziraphale as himself, as his actual self, white wings and light and ethereality, and knows that he used to be that way too, before. crowley leaves without saying anything; his actual self is more darkness and shadow, fire and smoke, terror and shame. 
  • when aziraphale knocks on his door later that night, firmly back in his soft, familiar body, crowley pretends not to have seen, not to have noticed, but he doesn’t look at aziraphale straight in the eyes either. not until aziraphale catches him by the arms and pulls him in, wrapping him in warmth and wings and two gentle hands. “I love you,” aziraphale says. “I love you exactly the way you are, not just the way you make yourself out to be.” and crowley looks for the sin of the lie in aziraphale’s eyes and when he doesn’t find it he just says, “oh. oh oh oh,” and aziraphale kisses him, finally kisses him, and crowley doesn’t remember heaven but oh, nothing’s better than this
  • two mornings later, aziraphale goes into the shop and finds a single rose in a bud vase on the counter. he picks it up and puts his nose to it, brushing his bottom lip against a petal, and suddenly finds himself with arms full of crowley, getting a very soft kiss. “good morning,” crowley says. “you could’ve come upstairs,” aziraphale says. “oh,” crowley says, smiling devilishly, leaning in for another kiss. “I’m going to.”

summary: it’s crowley who starts it. six weeks after the world doesn’t end, he shows up to the bookshop with a puzzle he nicked from a...
body:
• it’s crowley who starts it. six weeks after the world doesn’t end, he shows up to the bookshop with a puzzle he nicked from a tourist shop and says come on, angel, it’s not like we’ve got anything better to do with our time
  • aziraphale disapproves of nicking puzzles but likes the picture the puzzle makes - big ben lit up at night, reflected into the water of the thames - so instead of making crowley take it back, he just waters down crowley’s wine to make his point. crowley notices; in retribution, aziraphale’s glass turns into milk.
  • crowley expects the table that materialises to suit his usual seat on the sofa, and so the table does. the table does not, as a result, particularly suit aziraphale’s usual seat in his armchair. after a bit of hemming and hawing and awkward fussing, crowley finally reaches out and tugs aziraphale onto the sofa next to him. they don’t blush because they don’t go in for that sort of thing, but they can each tell that the other would be blushing if they did, and they each pretend not to notice it
  • as a result of this embarrassed sort of uncertain tension, they are drunk before they even have all four edges together
  • you can’t just miracle the pieces to fit aziraphale, that’s cheating. aziraphale gasps, put upon. i don’t cheat! i can’t cheat! crowley gives him a very unimpressed look over his glasses. aziraphale un-miracles the pieces and mimics crowley’s voice unflatteringly under his breath. 
  • crowley turns aziraphale’s drink to milk again. aziraphale turns it into bailey’s. 
  • aziraphale picks up a piece and studies it. it is a lush, green, shiny leaf. it absolutely does not belong in this puzzle of big ben and the thames. he looks down and notices that half the pieces now have shiny leaves on them. crowley, you can’t just change the picture halfway through! they’ll never go together now! crowley insists that he’s not doing it, but aziraphale’s not doing it, and someone must be. 
  • there is something else in the leaves. something that looks like the edges of two people.
  • they each reach for the same piece at the same time and knock hands. sorry, crowley says, withdrawing. no, aziraphale says, reaching out and taking crowley’s hand in his. it’s all right. 
  • they are now holding hands, which is making the puzzle very slow going. aziraphale is properly sloshed. crowley is plastered. 
  • look, aziraphale says. look at this. it’s me. it is him, his face on a little puzzle piece, looking toward something that has not been fitted into place yet. he giggles. crowley giggles. what’s the picture now, then? not fair to make me do it blind
  • i dunno, crowley says. they keep going. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle is smiling at whoever he is looking at. the green shiny leaves begin to shiver and part, revealing huge pink hibiscus and tiny white jasmine and orange and yellow lilies.
  • the second person is coming into form, slowly, shyly. the leaves have to part to let him through. 
  • it’s the last piece, aziraphale finally says, looking at the last piece. it is supposed to be the second person’s face. it is instead a piece with nothing but green shiny leaves on it. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle is looking at whoever it is adoringly.
  • angel, crowley says suddenly, i think we ought to be sober for it.
  • it’s not gabriel, is it? aziraphale asks, suddenly alarmed. 
  • crowley is sober in the next second. i don’t know, he says. i’m not changing it. 
  • aziraphale follows suit; the sudden sobriety makes his hand begin to sweat in crowley’s. i thought you were changing it! crowley shakes his head. it must be both of us. unconsciously. 
  • i never miracle unconsciously, aziraphale protests. well, mostly never. what kind of puzzle did you say this was anyway
  • only thing to do i guess is to fit it in and see who it is, crowley says. he hasn’t looked away from aziraphale-in-the-puzzle’s face, at the look of unqualified affection. he knows who he wants the other person to be. he doesn’t dare say it out loud.
  • aziraphale reaches out and puts the piece in: a green swatch where a face ought to be. all the leaves and flowers in the puzzle seem to rustle and shake for a moment. they part. the face is crowley’s. 
  • crowley-in-the-puzzle stares back at aziraphale-in-the-puzzle with the same adoring expression. it’s unmistakable. it’s inarguable. it’s ineffable. 
  • oh, aziraphale-on-the-sofa says softly. oh. did i put you in there, or did you?
  • crowley’s hand tightens around aziraphale’s. you would have put me in there? 
  • of course, aziraphale answers. he’s not looking at the puzzle anymore. he’s looking at crowley, crowley-on-the-sofa. his face is identical to the one in the puzzle. 
  • oh, crowley-on-the-sofa says. me–me too. i mean, i’d want to be there too. 
  • the puzzle shivers and shifts again. crowley-in-the-puzzle leans in. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle leans in.
  • oh, crowley-and-aziraphale-on-the-sofa say together. their hearts, which don’t even really need to be beating, are both pounding. 
  • i think, aziraphale says, the puzzle has a point.
  • do you? crowley says.
  • yeah, aziraphale says, i really do.
  • aziraphale-on-the-sofa leans in. crowley-on-the-sofa leans in. 
  • oh, aziraphale-on-the-sofa says again, and crowley-on-the-sofa tastes it from his mouth. oh. 
  • the puzzle blinks, and when they finally look again, minutes later or hours, big ben twinkles back at them, dazzling in the evening light.

  • aziraphale picks up a piece and studies it. it is a lush, green, shiny leaf. it absolutely does not belong in this puzzle of big ben and the thames. he looks down and notices that half the pieces now have shiny leaves on them. crowley, you can’t just change the picture halfway through! they’ll never go together now! crowley insists that he’s not doing it, but aziraphale’s not doing it, and someone must be. 
  • there is something else in the leaves. something that looks like the edges of two people.
  • they each reach for the same piece at the same time and knock hands. sorry, crowley says, withdrawing. no, aziraphale says, reaching out and taking crowley’s hand in his. it’s all right. 
  • they are now holding hands, which is making the puzzle very slow going. aziraphale is properly sloshed. crowley is plastered. 
  • look, aziraphale says. look at this. it’s me. it is him, his face on a little puzzle piece, looking toward something that has not been fitted into place yet. he giggles. crowley giggles. what’s the picture now, then? not fair to make me do it blind
  • i dunno, crowley says. they keep going. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle is smiling at whoever he is looking at. the green shiny leaves begin to shiver and part, revealing huge pink hibiscus and tiny white jasmine and orange and yellow lilies.
  • the second person is coming into form, slowly, shyly. the leaves have to part to let him through. 
  • it’s the last piece, aziraphale finally says, looking at the last piece. it is supposed to be the second person’s face. it is instead a piece with nothing but green shiny leaves on it. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle is looking at whoever it is adoringly.
  • angel, crowley says suddenly, i think we ought to be sober for it.
  • it’s not gabriel, is it? aziraphale asks, suddenly alarmed. 
  • crowley is sober in the next second. i don’t know, he says. i’m not changing it. 
  • aziraphale follows suit; the sudden sobriety makes his hand begin to sweat in crowley’s. i thought you were changing it! crowley shakes his head. it must be both of us. unconsciously. 
  • i never miracle unconsciously, aziraphale protests. well, mostly never. what kind of puzzle did you say this was anyway
  • only thing to do i guess is to fit it in and see who it is, crowley says. he hasn’t looked away from aziraphale-in-the-puzzle’s face, at the look of unqualified affection. he knows who he wants the other person to be. he doesn’t dare say it out loud.
  • aziraphale reaches out and puts the piece in: a green swatch where a face ought to be. all the leaves and flowers in the puzzle seem to rustle and shake for a moment. they part. the face is crowley’s. 
  • crowley-in-the-puzzle stares back at aziraphale-in-the-puzzle with the same adoring expression. it’s unmistakable. it’s inarguable. it’s ineffable. 
  • oh, aziraphale-on-the-sofa says softly. oh. did i put you in there, or did you?
  • crowley’s hand tightens around aziraphale’s. you would have put me in there? 
  • of course, aziraphale answers. he’s not looking at the puzzle anymore. he’s looking at crowley, crowley-on-the-sofa. his face is identical to the one in the puzzle. 
  • oh, crowley-on-the-sofa says. me–me too. i mean, i’d want to be there too. 
  • the puzzle shivers and shifts again. crowley-in-the-puzzle leans in. aziraphale-in-the-puzzle leans in.
  • oh, crowley-and-aziraphale-on-the-sofa say together. their hearts, which don’t even really need to be beating, are both pounding. 
  • i think, aziraphale says, the puzzle has a point.
  • do you? crowley says.
  • yeah, aziraphale says, i really do.
  • aziraphale-on-the-sofa leans in. crowley-on-the-sofa leans in. 
  • oh, aziraphale-on-the-sofa says again, and crowley-on-the-sofa tastes it from his mouth. oh. 
  • the puzzle blinks, and when they finally look again, minutes later or hours, big ben twinkles back at them, dazzling in the evening light.
